awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: PhysPort's impact on teaching practice
awd_abstract_narration:
PhysPort (http://physport.org) is a leading online professional development tool that supports physics faculty in implementing research-based teaching and assessment in their classrooms through expert recommendations about teaching, assessment, and results from physics education research. Physics education researchers have produced a variety of tools that vastly improve student learning of physics, and that have been adopted and adapted for other STEM fields. However, even educators who are aware of education research and highly motivated to improve their teaching have trouble getting necessary support to implement research-based teaching effectively. This project will study the impact of this tool for physics faculty teaching practice, conduct research to increase the tool's effectiveness, and advance understanding of how online resources can support faculty teaching practices across STEM disciplines.  

The goals of this project are to measure the impact of PhysPort on faculty teaching practice through multiple methods, including web analytics, website feedback, usability testing, and interviews about teaching practice. These measurements will determine whether the site is achieving its goals and how it can be improved to reach its full potential. Additionally, they provide information on how faculty use online professional development tools in general, which can be applied to the development of similar tools for all STEM disciplines. This project couples phenomenographic analyses of faculty perceptions of PhysPort's impact with quantitative analysis of their usage of the site. Interviews with faculty who are planning to or have recently changed their teaching practice will use the transtheoretical model to track faculty attitudes and behaviors through the change process. The results of this research will be used to implement changes to PhysPort's resources and disseminated to other researchers in faculty change.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF PHYSICS TEACHERS, INCORPORATED

por.por_cntn:
Broader Impacts:

PhysPort.org is a website that supports physics faculty in using research-based teaching and assessment. PhysPort is widely used throughout the physics community; over 20% of US physics faculty are verified educators on PhysPort. In this project we have publicized PhysPort through presentations and workshops at national and international meetings. PhysPort has been integrated into the Faculty Teaching Institute, a biyearly intensive workshop for new faculty in physics and astronomy. PhysPort was particularly impactful during the covid-19 pandemic when we published a series of articles with resources for moving physics courses online, and our usage surged during this time.

Intellectual Merit:

We interviewed 23 physics faculty about how they decide to try new teaching ideas in their classes, including upper-level classes, how they implement these ideas, and what resources they need. We conducted follow-up interviews with 7 of these faculty, including several who were teaching upper-level physics courses, to understand how they made changes to their teaching over a period of 2 or more years. 

These interviews informed our development of a model that we call the “asset-based agentic paradigm” of teaching change. For decades, physics education researchers have developed research-based teaching methods and materials, and research in what we call the “teaching-method-centered paradigm” has focused on the degree to which faculty use these methods and materials, either with fidelity or with adaptation. In our research, we found that faculty rarely framed what they were doing as implementing or even adapting particular teaching methods and materials, but instead used their agency to enact change according to their own values and productive ideas, using research-based teaching methods and materials as tools to support their own goals. The teaching-method-centered paradigm supports top-down dissemination, in which curriculum developers make high-quality teaching materials available to faculty and provide support for implementing a complete set of materials. In contrast, the asset-based agentic paradigm supports providing faculty with access to a wide variety of teaching resources from different sources to support different goals, providing guidance for faculty to understand how to use them, and supporting faculty in adapting materials to their own needs.

We interviewed 12 faculty who had experience using PhysPort to get resources for their teaching to find out in what ways the site was helping them, and how it could be improved. We also conducted usability testing of the live site with 11 physics faculty to study how they interacted with the site, what they were able to do on the site, and what they were not. Here are the key results of these interviews:

  • Physics faculty find PhysPort to be a valuable resource. They use it to get inspired and feel connected to a community of others doing the same kind of teaching, answer practical questions in their teaching, measure the effectiveness of their teaching using research-based assessments, compare their assessment scores to national averages, organize and view their results over time, share assessment results (and national average for context) with their departments for promotion, find research-based materials to use in their courses, find high quality example materials as models for materials they create themselves, plan for TA training, explain some aspect of education research to their colleagues, and get started with using education research in their classes.

  • Faculty are often pleasantly surprised by the depth and richness of content on PhysPort, which is not evident to them from a first glance at the site.

  • The most popular parts of PhysPort are the assessments and expert recommendations. Most faculty are able to find what they are looking for in these sections and find them extremely useful.

  • Faculty find the homepage to be dated and cluttered and have trouble navigating it.

  • The organization of the teaching methods and curricula are confusing to faculty and they don’t understand the difference between these two parts of the site.

We used the results of our research with physics faculty to redesign the site to better meet their needs and address the problems we found. Key aspects of our site redesign included:

  • Redesigning the homepage to better support users in understanding what you can do on PhysPort and discovering useful resources

  • Organizing the site around collections of materials of different types that address common goals of faculty coming to PhysPort

  • Combining teaching methods and materials with curricula and making both easier to find in contexts where users are likely to be looking for them

  • Restructuring the pages for individual assessments and teaching methods to clearly present the information users are looking for in the order they are looking for it

  • Better integrating hard-to-find pieces of the site into the overall site structure so they are more findable

  • Giving the site a more modern look and feel and making it easier to find new content

  • Adding new content to fill identified gaps
